name: Lille
fun_fact: Fun fact: Lille was the capital of Flanders for centuries, which is why its cuisine is more Belgian than French - you'll find more beer-based stews and waffles here than anywhere else in France, creating a delicious cultural identity crisis on every plate.

hero_dishes.name: Carbonade Flamande
hero_dishes.description: Beef slow-cooked with lard, onions, herbs, and a sauce made with beer, sugar, mustard, and vinegar - served with homemade bread for soaking up the rich gravy
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Flemish beer stew is Lille's answer to French beef bourguignon, but using Belgian beer instead of wine. It reflects Lille's unique position as a French city with a Flemish soul
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Estaminet Aux Vieux de la Vielle, A Taaable, La HoublonniÃ¨re

hero_dishes.name: Le Welsh
hero_dishes.description: Beer and cheese boiled together, poured over toast and ham, baked until golden brown, and topped with a fried egg
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lille's version of Welsh rarebit adds ham and beer, making it distinctly Flemish. It's the ultimate hangover cure and a test of how much rich food you can handle in one sitting
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Estaminet La Pate Brisee (10 minutes north of city center), traditional estaminets

hero_dishes.name: Potjevleesch (Le Potch)
hero_dishes.description: Various meats (pork, beef, veal, rabbit, or chicken) marinated and cooked together in beer or white wine with spices, served cold in vinegar gelatin
hero_dishes.origin_story: Translating to 'pot of meat', this dish represents Flemish resourcefulness - using whatever meats are available and preserving them in gelatin. It's an acquired taste that locals swear by
hero_dishes.where_to_find: L'Estaminet Le Rijsel, Le Barbue d'Anvers, Les Compagnons de la Grappe

hero_dishes.name: Gaufre Lilloise
hero_dishes.description: Thin, soft waffles filled with creamy vanilla or vergeoise (brown sugar) butter filling - delicate and subtly sweet
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the 18th century at Maison Meert, these waffles became famous when General de Gaulle (who was from Lille) had them shipped to Paris regularly. They're nothing like thick Belgian waffles
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Maison Meert (historic patisserie - the original since 1761)

signature_drinks.name: Flemish Beer
signature_drinks.description: Belgian-style beers ranging from blonde ales to dark abbey beers, many brewed locally
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Beer is used in cooking and drinking equally in Lille. Locals pair specific beers with different dishes at estaminets, and debate beer choices as seriously as Parisians debate wine

signature_drinks.name: Chicory Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Coffee blended with roasted chicory root - slightly bitter and earthy
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Chicory coffee has been a Lille tradition since the Napoleonic blockade when coffee was scarce. Some traditionalists still prefer it to pure coffee

food_culture_notes: Estaminets are traditional Flemish restaurants with warm interiors, old objects on walls, and hop garlands hanging from ceilings
Lille's cuisine is predominantly Flemish, sharing more with Belgian and Dutch food than with Paris
The city has a thriving friteries culture - small fast-food spots where the specialty is perfectly crispy fries
Maroilles cheese from the region is so pungent it's banned on public transportation, but locals love it in tarts

unique_modern: high-speed rail connecting to Brussels and Paris
